layoutType.description: Algorithms that require a planar or upward planar graph. Most of these algorithms are theoretically interesting, but not practically usable.
layoutType.name: Planar

layoutAlgorithm.description: Sugiyama's layout algorithm, based on Gansner et al. 1993 and Sander 1996. This method emphasizes the direction of edges by reversing as few edges as possible. Nodes are arranged in horizontal layers.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Sugiyama

layoutAlgorithm.description: A planarization-based algorithm based on Gutwenger and Mutzel '04. The main emphasis is put on the minimization of the number of edge crossings. Edges are routed orthogonally, which is achieved through the "topology-shape-metrics" approach by Batini, Nardelli and Tamassia '86. The algorithm also contains special treatment for mixed-upward drawings in order to support UML class diagrams, where generalizations need to be handled differently from other edge types.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Planarization

layoutAlgorithm.description: The fast multipole multilevel layout algorithm, after Hachul and Juenger 2004. This force-directed drawing method is suited also for very large graphs. It is based on a combination of an efficient multilevel scheme and a strategy for approximating the repusive forces in the system by rapidly evaluating potential fields.
layoutAlgorithm.name: FMMM

layoutAlgorithm.description: Force-based algorithm after Davidson and Harel 1996, applying the paradigm of simulated annealing. This is applicable for undirected graphs with straight-line connections.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Davidson-Harel

layoutAlgorithm.description: Force-based algorithm after Fruchterman and Reingold 1991. This is a modification of the spring-embedder model of Eades for undirected graphs with straight edges. The heuristic strives for uniform edge lengths, and is developed in analogy to forces in natural systems.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Fruchterman-Reingold

layoutAlgorithm.description: Energy-based "Graph Embedder" algorithm after Frick, Ludwig, and Mehldau 1995. The method is based on the spring-embedder paradigm and contains several heuristics to improve the convergence, including local temperatures, gravitational forces, and the detection of rotations and oscillations.
layoutAlgorithm.name: GEM

layoutAlgorithm.description: Circular layout after Dogrusoz, Madden and Madden 1997. The layouts emphasize natural group structures inherent in a graph's topology, which is well suited for ring and star network topologies. The nodes are clustered by biconnectivity or node degree and are positioned on radiating circles.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Circular

layoutAlgorithm.description: Specialized algorithm for trees, after Buchheim, Juenger and Leipert '06. The branches of the tree are arranged in a given direction.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Tree

layoutAlgorithm.description: Specialized algorithm for trees. Nodes are arranged radially around the root.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Radial Tree

layoutAlgorithm.description: Upward planarization layout by Chimani, Gutwenger, Mutzel and Wong '10. While usual layer-based methods first determine a layering and then minimize crossings, this approach aims at directly computing an upward planar representation (UPR), where edge crossings are represented by dummy vertices. A layering is then derived from this UPR, which also induces a node order in each layer. This leads to significantly less edge crossings compared to former methods, while the overall edge direction is still preserved. The input graph must be connected.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Upward-Planarization

layoutAlgorithm.description: The Fast-Multipole-Embedder layout algorithm.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Fast Multipole

layoutAlgorithm.description: The Fast-Multipole-Multilevel-Embedder layout algorithm.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Fast Multipole Multilevel

layoutAlgorithm.description: The spring-embedder layout algorithm after Kamada and Kawai 1989. The input graph must be connected.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Kamada-Kawai

layoutAlgorithm.description: Stress majorization layout that allows radial constraints based on shortest path distances. The implementation is based on Brandes and Pich 2009. The input graph must be connected.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Stress Majorization

layoutAlgorithm.description: Dominance layout method. The input graph must be connected.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Dominance

layoutAlgorithm.description: Visibility layout method. The input graph must be connected.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Visibility

layoutAlgorithm.description: The layout algorithm by de Fraysseix, Pach, and Pollack 1990. This algorithm draws a planar graph straight-line without crossings. The algorithm runs in three phases. In the ﬁrst phase, the graph is augmented by adding new artiﬁcial edges to get a triangulated plane graph. Then, a so-called shelling order (also called canonical ordering) for triangulated planar graphs is computed. In the third phase the vertices are placed incrementally according to the shelling order. The input graph must be planar and connected and must not contain multi-edges.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Fraysseix-Pach-Pollack

layoutAlgorithm.description: The layout algorithm by Schnyder 1990. This algorithm draws a planar graph straight-line without crossings. The algorithm runs in three phases. In the ﬁrst phase, the graph is augmented by adding new artiﬁcial edges to get a triangulated plane graph. Then, a partition of the set of interior edges in three trees (also called Schnyder trees) with special orientation properties is derived. In the third step, the actual coordinates are computed. The input graph must be planar and connected and must not contain multi-edges.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Schnyder

layoutAlgorithm.description: A straight-line drawing algorithm for planar graphs after Kant 1996. The algorithm runs in several phases. In the first phase, the graph is augmented by adding edges to achieve a certain connectivity (e.g., biconnected or triconnected). Then, a shelling order of the the resulting graph is computed. The input graph must be planar and must not contain multi-edges.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Canonical Order

layoutAlgorithm.description: The Mixed-Model layout algorithm by Gutwenger and Mutzel 1998, which is based upon ideas by Kant. In particular, Kant's algorithm has been changed concerning the placement phase and the vertex boxes, and it has been generalized to work for connected planar graphs. This algorithm draws a d-planar graph on a grid such that every edge has at most three bends and the minimum angle between two edges is at least 2/d radians. The algorithm runs in several phases. In the preprocessing phase, vertices with degree one are temporarily deleted and the graph is being augmented to a biconnected planar graph using a planar biconnectivity augmentation module. Then, a shelling order for biconnected plane graphs is computed. In the next step, boxes around each vertex are defined in such a way that the incident edges appear regularly along the box. Finally, the coordinates of the vertex boxes are computed taking the degree-one vertices into account. The input graph must not contain multi-edges.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Mixed Model

layoutAlgorithm.description: A straight-line drawing algorithm for planar graphs after Chrobak and Kant 1997. The algorithm runs in several phases. In the first phase, the graph is augmented by adding edges to achieve a certain connectivity (e.g., biconnected or triconnected). Then, a shelling order of the the resulting graph is computed. The input graph must be planar and must not contain multi-edges.
layoutAlgorithm.name: Convex Grid

layoutOption.description: The number of iterations performed by the algorithm
layoutOption.name: Iterations

layoutOption.description: Distance of edge labels to the nodes
layoutOption.name: Label Distance

layoutOption.description: Spacing of edge labels to the edge
layoutOption.name: Label Spacing

layoutOption.description: Defines the costs used in the algorithm
layoutOption.name: Costs

layoutOption.description: The number of times that the number of crossings may not decrease after a complete top-down bottom-up traversal, before a run is terminated
layoutOption.name: Fails

layoutOption.description: The fineness option used in the algorithm
layoutOption.name: Fineness

layoutOption.description: The initial temperature
layoutOption.name: Initial Temperature

layoutOption.description: If preprocessing of cliques is enabled, this option determines the minimal size of cliques to search for
layoutOption.name: Minimum Clique Size

layoutOption.description: Sets whether the initial placement is different on every algorithm call
layoutOption.name: New Initial Placement

layoutOption.description: If set to true, a preprocessing for cliques (complete subgraphs) is performed and cliques will be laid out in a special form (straight-line, not orthogonal). The preprocessing may reduce running time and improve layout quality if the input graphs contains dense subgraphs.
layoutOption.name: Preprocess Cliques

layoutOption.description: Specifies whether the algorithm prioritizes quality or speed
layoutOption.name: Quality vs Speed

layoutOption.description: Factor for the spacing between connected components
layoutOption.name: Component Spacing Factor

layoutOption.description: Defines the costs for association edges
layoutOption.name: Cost for Association Edges

layoutOption.description: Defines the costs for generalization edges
layoutOption.name: Cost for Generalization Edges

layoutOption.description: Determines how many times the crossing minimization phase (Sugiyama) or planar subgraph phase (Planarization) is repeated.
layoutOption.name: Runs

layoutOption.description: Defines the temperature and the number of iterations
layoutOption.name: Speed

layoutOption.description: The opening angle for rotations in radians (between 0 and pi/2)
layoutOption.name: Rotation Angle

layoutOption.description: The rotation sensitivity (between 0 and 1)
layoutOption.name: Rotation Sensitivity

layoutOption.description: Determines whether the transpose step is performed after each 2-layer crossing minimization; this step tries to reduce the number of crossings by switching neighbored nodes on a layer
layoutOption.name: Transpose

layoutOption.description: The used formula for attraction
layoutOption.name: Attraction Formula

layoutOption.description: Factor for the minimal distance between father and child components
layoutOption.name: Level Spacing Factor

layoutOption.description: The maximal number of rounds per node
layoutOption.name: Number Of Rounds

layoutOption.description: The opening angle for oscillations in radians (between 0 and pi/2)
layoutOption.name: Oscillation Angle

layoutOption.description: The oscillation sensitivity (between 0 and 1)
layoutOption.name: Oscillation Sensitivity

layoutOption.description: The minimal temperature
layoutOption.name: Minimal Temperature

layoutOption.description: The maximal disturbance.
layoutOption.name: Maximal Disturbance

layoutOption.description: The gravitational constant
layoutOption.name: Gravitational Constant

layoutOption.description: Factor for the horizontal spacing between adjacent subtrees
layoutOption.name: Subtree Spacing Factor

layoutOption.description: If set to true, small random perturbations are performed
layoutOption.name: Noise

layoutOption.description: Whether edge labels shall be processed
layoutOption.name: Place Labels

layoutOption.description: The number of coefficients for expansions
layoutOption.name: Precision

layoutOption.description: Tolerance below which the system is regarded stable and the optimization is stopped
layoutOption.name: Stop Tolerance

layoutOption.description: Add upward constraints
layoutOption.name: Upward

layoutOption.description: Add radial constraints
layoutOption.name: Radial

layoutOption.description: Ratio of the nodes on the external face giving a limit for the number of nodes placed on the base line
layoutOption.name: Base Ratio

layoutOption.description: The module for finding an acyclic subgraph
layoutOption.name: Acyclic Subgraph Module

layoutOption.description: The module for computing a layering (ranking) of the graph
layoutOption.name: Layering Module

layoutOption.description: The maximal width of the Coffman-Graham layering
layoutOption.name: Layering Width

layoutOption.description: The module for crossing minimization used in the layer-sweep method
layoutOption.name: Crossing Min. Module

layoutOption.description: The module for edge insertion used for planarization
layoutOption.name: Edge Insertion Module

layoutOption.description: The module for choosing an embedding for the graph
layoutOption.name: Embedder Module

layoutOption.description: Factor for scaling the bounding box of the initial layout
layoutOption.name: Scale Factor

layoutOption.description: The module for crossing beautification
layoutOption.name: Crossing Beautifier

layoutOption.description: Whether ports should be moved to the point where edges cross the node's bounds.
layoutOption.name: Adapt Port Positions
